Robert Watkins wrote:

>>Nobody disputes that 100% code coverage is a good thing, it's just that it
>>becomes impossibly hard to achieve as your code base becomes more complex.
>>You just need to make sure you don't hit the point of diminishing return
>>when trying to hit a balance between "more code coverage", "more tests",
>>"bug fixes" and "more features".
>>    
>>
>The other part, of course, is that 100% code coverage still doesn't
>mean you've tested everything... there will still be logic paths
>through the code that are not exercised, and in any large enough
>program (say, above 10000 lines), these paths rapidly approach
>infiinty.
>
>Bob Glass' "Facts and Fallacies" has a good write-up on this.
>  
>
  I have to completely disagree with this.

  First of all we are talking about unit tests, which suppose to work 
with isolated components. I'll leave aside discussion that you can't 
always isolate components from the infrastructure because it is a 
separate topic and in fact quite achievable in my opinion.

  Now, for each isolated unit of code we have an unit test. When 
application size grows complexity of unit tests would grow linearly and 
not exponential and as a result close to 100% test coverage is not any 
more difficult to achieve for large codebase then for a small codebase.

  Last thing I want to point out is that in many cases folks talk about 
test coverage based on the percent of covered lines. This is one of the 
easies coverage methodologies and also the one of the least 
representative. There are more meaningful coverage techniques that would 
give better representation of the tested logic paths. It also seems very 
logical to me to assume that well designed code will not have infinite 
number of logical branches for any given code unit.
  I agree that there could be some code patterns that doesn't make sense 
to test explicitly, but coverage tool can actually exclude such patterns 
from the analysis.

  For those who curious about coverage analysis methodologies I can 
suggest a good summary at http://www.bullseye.com/coverage.html

  regards,
  Eugene
